body.p:
Perhaps I ought to have
replied ere this to your form received the day before
I left New York, but I have deferred until now
answering your letter in hopes of having something
to say that might interest you.

The Box sent by Express to me in N York
gave me a great deal of bother & trouble, indeed
if it had not so happened that my brother Alexr
intended to see me off, it would not have come
to or with me. I must say I felt somewhat put out
at receiving your letter stating that you would
send it, after my particular & respected requests to
you to ship it with other things direct from
your city. The bother of this box received as it was
on the day of my departure caused me to miss
the company of my dear Parents, during the last
half hour of my stay in their city, after their
taking the trouble & undergoing the fatigue of coming
down to the vessel.

It was recd too late to bring as freight & therefore
I had to watch it with my baggage all the way to NO, particularly
when the California boys were hauling & dragging their baggage

from ship to ship at Havana. And then
on my arrival here I had fresh difficulties
to encounter before I could get possession
of it. I say nothing about some three or four
dollars very unnecessary expenses incurred and
which I had to pay out of my pocket. I had
quite enough to see to in leaving N York without
at the very least moment being worried about
a box of silver which if received here now would
be in plenty of time.

I speak as I do about this affair for
your sake & to show you how seriously you
may inconvenience a friend by not properly
considering his entire situation. Alexander will
tell you how unhandsomely Adams & Co behaved.
They performed but a very small part of their contract
with you. By the by—Did you pay them for taking the
box to NY. They said you had not & made me pay 14/—&
then they would not send it on board. Alexander attended
to getting it & had to bring it to the vessel on the back of a carriage
about ½ hour before we left, & the job we had to set it
on board only was enough to set one crazy.

Your shipment to Mr Touro is all right
we have all the Bill Loding? calls for & the keys also from
the captain. Mr Touro told me a day or two ago that
he would soon reply to your letter, which I read. I presume
he has done so. I forget the date of it. We have not
opened any of the boxes as yet, but will very soon—

With regard to a Minister the Consecration &c—
We have written to Mr Nathan offering him
$25.00. He must be here by the 1st proximo or else
he will decline. If he comes he will only remain
till 20th Jany, then return to Jamaica & be
here again before “Sehbuot” so he said in his letter
to me recd shortly after my arrival here. The
congregation do not want the consecration to take
place until we have a resident minister. I would
prefer otherwise particularly if it could be say middle
of Jany when you could be here; but I can not
say what they will do. From the tener of your last letter
to Mr Touro I hope he will ask you to come, or that he
will say to me that he will pay your expenses. If he does
I will do the rest between my congr & yours to secure your
presence here. I have done you the fullest justice in the
sight of Mr. T & also in that of the congregation ?
they say “I swear by your name”. So you see if I have any
complaints to make against you (as in the first part of this
letter) I make them to you only. That is my system.—

The German congr have sent a proposal
of $1500 to Mr Gutheim & I have little doubt that
he will accept & they will have the man that ought to
have been here now performing the services for us. I shall
not be in the least surprised if Mr. Nathan does not
come after all & then “we will be in a boat”. Alas.

I hope you are getting along better with your flock.
I fear they (or some of them) will not appreciate you
until they lose you or come very near it. Such is pure human nature.

The revd Mr Raphael seems to be making quite
a stir in your part of the country, and indeed
many of us here are very anxious to hear & see
him. I think he will not regret his visit to
the US.

I am still kept pretty busy with finishing
the Synagogue & attending to the duties of my office
as President Heb. Benevolent Association & shall be happy
when some aspiring gentleman will take charge of
these matters & relieve me. In good earth I have
served long enough & now only see the glimmerings
of some little satisfaction.

It pains me to think that Mr Wm F's health
will not permit his leaving home. What do you candidly
think of his situation entre-vous. My dear little Aunt
is quite better (stronger) I hear; will you give my love
to them both. I presume you see them as often as
when we used so pleasantly to meet beneath their
hospitable roof.

Knowing that you feel interested in my
welfare I name having gone into my old business as a h?
I am happy to say that I am doing very fairly indeed.

Let me hear from you my dear friend when
convenience & the humor may permit. How is your
health I trust better than heretofore.

This ought to reach you in “Hanuca” may
you enjoy the festival in health & contentment
